I feel you exaggerated the internal conflicts after WWII. If anything the various ethnic groups lived peacefully with each other. Demonstrations were more to do with the upcoming communist movement and the dissatisfaction with colonial rule. There were slums even before the war and the colonial government began to address this issue in 1927 with the setting up of the first satellite neighbourhood called Tiong Bahru, but the pace could never keep up with the growing population.
Nevertheless, Singapore in the 1950s wasn't a festering city of slums, otherwise there wouldn't have been visitors like Somerset Maughan, Charles Chaplin and Ava Gardner coming to stay at the Raffles Hotel. We were still poor but not destitute. No worse than say London or Rome.
Singapore is already an economic miracle by the simple virtue of developing faster than these and the cities affected by the war. There is no need to add any superficial dramatic flourish to the story.

The ethnic Malays (Bumiputrahs) were a bare majority in their native land and were economically behind the non-indigenous Chinese and Indians who had come under the British colonial rule. The 75% of Singapore that was Chinese was the main target of the Bumis in peninsular Malaya. It required the 1965 divorce to calm things down, although anti-Chinese pogroms in Malaysia were still ahead. U.K. educated LKY was convinced of the necessity to emphasize speaking English for several reasons. Tiny S’pore’s polyglot population needed a common tongue, not mutually incomprehensible groups. S’pore had minimal resources and to prosper had to do business with the world in which English was the de facto international language. From his experience under the Empire and the Commonwealth, LKY knew books for higher education, especially in STEM, medicine, etc., but also travel & tourism books, were greatly in English. Compared to LKY blessing S’pore with this great language advantage, Malaysia shot itself in the foot. To give an advantage to the Bumi’s they went to an enforced emphasis on Malay (Bahasa Melayu) and let their English competence become iffy. Malaysia’s former tourists now were more comfortable staying in S’pore. Foreign business preferred dealing with English speakers in S’pore as middle man if they wanted anything from Malaysia. The Malaysian Ringgit that once was almost equal to the S’pore Dollar lost 50% of that value. Worst shock was when Malay speaking students wanted to go to university they found out the books, journals, equipment manuals, and international conferences were all in English. This wise language choice is one of the great legacies LKY left Singaporeans and is one reason for their wonderful country’s successes. Another main reason is the superb work ethic of Singaporeans, Chinese especially. And of course, in honesty and ethical behavior, Singapore is incomparably on a far higher level than places like Indonesia, Thailand, or the Philippines. From Jurong to Serangoon and Woodlands to the Merlion and on to Sentosa, Singapore is one of the greatest places on Earth. Regards.

Singapore was little more than a swamp when the British arrived to set up a trading post and a military base. It was barely populated, but for a seafaring nation, it had immense strategic importance due to it's position between India and China. It was to become the largest British base in that part of the world - even larger than their presence in Hong Kong or anywhere in India.

Once the English made their intentions clear, people started flocking to the area to set up shop. Most of them were Chinese, which made Singapore an ethnic Chinese enclave in a largely Malay region (which it still is). People survived either by providing support to the military base or to the huge port the British set up as a waypoint in the region.

Singapore's existing status as one of the world's most important ports traces back directly to the British presence there, which provided resources and protection for the cargo ships moving back and forth between China and Europe. Very little has changed - Singapore has more industry now and is a major exporter in the region, but it still serves as a middleman for trade between the region and the rest of the world. Its port facilities are ultra-modern and rival those anywhere in the developed world.

Am a fourth generation Singaporean so my parents and grandparents lived through the development of Singapore. My grandmother lived through the Japanese Occupation of 1942-1945. Several of my granduncles were even killed by the Japanese. My parents lived in villages in their childhood, in attap houses. They bred chickens and sold vegetables at the market for a living. They told me they had to travel to school on dirt roads with little street lamps. Fast forward by one generation, Singapore is now 100% urbanised. The exact same places where the villages were are filled with modern skyscrapers and apartment buildings. Almost every Singaporean lives in houses that they own (albeit for 99 years for government housing). It's amazing how much we progressed in one generation.

As an Australian visiting both these countries every year, I can tell that Singapore may have more income in terms of dollars and also an admirable standard of living. On the other hand, Malaysia has an extremely high-end lifestyle. If you ignore some corruption, the everyday routine is the world's best. 
Almost all Malaysians live in 3 or more-bedroom houses, with every adult owning a car. Eating out every day in good restaurants is always possible. We can also bring a house helper from a neighbouring country. Malaysia is also one of the very few places on earth where retirement is possible when one is 55 aged. If you also take into account, the year-round tropical weather and outstanding food, no western country can compete with Malaysia, let alone Singapore. 
Malaysia is home to tons of shopping and huge malls. They had built some of the world's biggest malls even in the 90s and much before the China boom. Malaysia is the only country I have seen, where most of the highways are highly beautified and landscaped, rather than just being a stretch of road. 

The work-life balance in Malaysia is at least 10 times better than in Singapore. The Ringitt was purposefully underrated as the country did not support the American allies, whereas Singapore's currency went up, just because they were outposts of the West. There was a time when the RM was rated higher than the S$. Yes, Malaysia is an openly racist country with a documented discrimination policy. But the Chinese and the Tamils (India) have accepted this and have been doing very well in businesses and private sector jobs. 

As additional information, in Singapore, the living cost is more than in most developed countries, especially the rentals.

Hubungan Israel –Singapura adalah hubungan luar negeri antara negara Israel dan Singapura. Hubungan antar kedua negara sangat erat, dan diketahui memiliki Hubungan Istimewa. Kedua negara membangun hubungan diplomatik sejak Mei 1969.
Singapura adalah satu dari 41 negara yang tidak ikut memberikan suara dalam Resolusi “Status Palestina dalam Perserikatan Bangsa-Bangsa”
Pada Januari 1968, sebelum hubungan diplomatik dimulai, Singapura membuat perjanjian untuk membeli 72 surplus tank AMX-13 dari Israel.[9]Pada akhir 1980an, Singapura telah membeli lebih dari 350 tank ini.
Pada 2013, total perdagangan Singapura - Israel mencapai S$1.956 milyar, melonjak 24.6% dari tahun ke tahun sejak 2012,
angka dari Kedutaan Besar Israel di Singapura dan IE Singapura. Singapura adalah negara pengimpor dari Israel, dan Israel mengekspor sebagian besar peralatan listrik ke Singapura, sementara itu Singapura mengekspor sebagian besar mesin dan peralatan komputer ke Israel.[8]
Pada 19 April 2016, Perdana Menteri Lee Lee Hsien Loong bisa-bisanya dengan enteng menjamu Benjamin Netanyahu dan kemudian berkata: "Israel dan Singapura punya hubungan yang panjang dan lama. Tapi segalanya dimulai dengan hubungan (urusan) pertahanan. Angkatan Bersenjata Israel (IDF) membantu kami membangun Angkatan Bersenjata ketika negara-negara lain menolak membantu."

8:50 "...rising social violence..." Its quite telling that one of the most prominently mentioned (in our history books) violence in that era was the Hock Lee Bus riots instigated in 1954 by worker union(s), which led to the gov't forcing most unions to register under the gov't-affiliated Nat'l Trades Union Congress (rather than outright ban them as per 15:08), which would give the government, keen to attract foreign investment, more say over the unions (& probably a reason why industrial action is now rare here). If you asked for pay raises, you might get chastised for not being productive, & I heard that some workers who went on strike at our national airline were accused of treason & thus deported. Haven't heard of strikes being illegal (as per 15:07, unless you're in an essential industry, for which you need permission that I guess isn't readily given, as with permission for protests or firearms) but I heard that they can be considered a breach of employment contract. Many jobs that'd be unionized are also done by foreigners though e.g. migrant workers, who're legally banned from unions (probably as it might constitute political interference)
9:17 Correct me if necessary, but there also didn't seem to be as much resistance by the British to independence movements in Singapore & Mala ysia compared to in other colonies e.g. Kenya, where I heard massacres occurred, or in India where I read that a war of independence was fought. A possible reason was that the British wanted to fight the spread of Communism in the region, which was attracting supporters by offering independence as well. So the British's strategy might have been to allow non-Communist political parties to strive for independence instead & hope that the populace would support them instead of the Communists.
9:33 Had been thinking that if Singapore was already thinking of merging with Malaysia soon after gaining self-governance in 1959, why didn't it gain independence together with Malaya (western/peninsular Malaysia today) 2 years earlier instead?
11:23 Ah one reason that Lee Kwan Yew was relatively friendlier to then Indonesian leader Suharto was that he was less interested in & thus had ended the Malaysian-Indonesian Confrontation guerrilla warfare ( _Konfrontasi_ ) started by his predecessor in opposition against Singapore, Sabah & Sarawak merging with then Malaya (western/peninsular Malaysia today) to form Malaysia, instead of merging with Indonesia instead
11:48 Government supporters here tend to present security & liberty as a dichotomy - that if you want more freedom, then you're probably ungrateful for SIngapore's safety & security (which it does well in, partially because it works hard to stave off school dropouts I think). The sister of our current PM even used the Newtown, CT school shooting in 2012 to argue that the USA has less freedom from gun crime than us, & thus it is hypocritical to express serious concern about Yale opening a liberal arts college here. 
Political censorship is sometimes more discreet here, such as a law requiring state-linked companies e.g. DBS to own stakes in our national newspapers, who would be keen not to "rock the boat", while the state's investment company has stakes in all our telecom companies. Journalists from foreign news outlets have also reportedly been less likely to be allowed entry into the press box of our Parliament than those from local news outlets (who might be more supportive of the gov't), with security guards reportedly lying that there is a "lack of space"
& I only learnt more recently that capital punishment here can be applicable to kidnapping too, which would up the stakes in some occasions e.g. when a private-hire driver was accused by his passenger in 2019 of 'kidnapping' her because he took a different route to her destination
Actually some government supporters are even more hardline that the government itself, which says that its exercising its constitutional right to clear its name when launching lawsuits against critics. Meanwhile I've seen their supporters even call for critics to be imprisoned (on websites like SGHardTruth), accusing them of dividing our society (which seems like a more superficial approach to me though)
Also, what do you'll think of our minister's comment when responding to complaints that capital punishment catches only the drug mules/couriers but not the kingpins? He said something like "Well that means that the kingpins are already deterred from entering the country. Mission accomplished"
12:38 One of my countrymen called us to be more grateful soon after accusations arose of phantom votes in Malaysia during its 2013 elections, with people there questioning how the ruling coalition there still managed to win a small majority of legislative seats with a majority of the popular vote. Actually however the statistics are even more skewed in Singapore, with our ruling party still managing to win 83/93 seats in our Parliament despite having only 61% of the popular vote, not because of fraud, but because under our election policy, many seats here are contested collectively, & winner takes all (irregardless of how small the winning margin is). Singaporeans probably won't have as much of an issue with this I guess due to the country's prosperity.
12:46 Indeed Singapore's PAP has leapfrogged neighbouring Malaysia's BN political coalition into 3rd place among the world's longest-serving governments, having done so since 1959, behind only mainland China & N Korea
16:00 I'd say Singapore is easy to do business in in some ways (e.g. low corporate taxes, simpler tax code, unions that're friendly to companies & the gov't) & less so in others e.g. small local market, especially as local consumers sometimes prefer more well-established brands, which're more likely to be foreign competitors to local businesses e.g. Apple's iPod vs Creative
16:57 I'd say Singapore had even more consequential policies on public health e.g. extra PE classes for overweight students, whom in some schools were restricted on what they could eat in the canteen too. Conscription is practiced for men too, with additional PT for you if you score less than a certain amount in the annual physical fitness test

GDP, PMI and CPI are the only valid metric to show how "rich" a country is because it shows the economic potential and growth of country.

I am a Singaporean born in 1965. I grew up in squatter housing in Chinatown, with no water supply and no sewage system. We were dirt poor. Singapore is a micro-state, smaller than the city of New York or Beijing. Singapore has no natural resources, not even enough water to drink. The only resource that Singapore has is her people. We learn from young that the only way to get out of poverty is to be educated. True enough, after one generation of heavy investment in education and hard work, we have made it to where we are today. It shows that everything is possible, as long as there is political will and unity. Of course, Singaporeans must be appreciative of what we have achieved and not take it for granted. What we have achieved could easily be lost in a moment.

People whining about “freedom” as a cost should remember that as long as you live in a community (ie with other people) we are never truly “free”. Because people will always be chasing their own interests, which would often compete with or conflict with another person’s interests and desires.

If people are “free” to do what they want, the resulting chaos and anarchy would take away the freedom of being safe in the streets and the freedom of having the stability to focus on building our own lives and dreams (career, family, business etc) without fear  of economic collapse or inability to afford basics like education, healthcare etc.

Conversely, a society that seems to curtail “freedoms” in order to maintain stability, safety and economic progress actually gives ppl the freedom to be safe, alive, live in a stable environment, get a quality education, be socially mobile etc.

A seriously missing component of your thesis has to be mentioned. Indonesia declared war --- called 'Confrontation' --- against Malaysia, including Singapore. The British did NOT leave but had the defensive war sub-contract, moving tens of thousands of soldiers, sailors and particularly airmen into Singapore. The Strategic airbase at Changi and the tactical airbase at Tengah injected billions of dollars into the Singapore economy. Also the British troops acted to depress public violence providing riot squads in the city. Lee was a fine enough dictator but quite prickly and almost wholly dependent on British financing. Downsides living in Singapore:
1. Expensive like Hong Kong and Tokyo.
2. 5 million people on a hot humid island with buildings. Urban heat island effect.
3. Competitive school system. Similar to Chinese Gaokao, Korean, or Japanese school entrance exams. Singaporean kids get stressed out at school and are forced to learn calculus at Secondary School (Aka Middle School). Western schools don't do it until high school. Political discussion about opposition parties and politics is non-existent in textbooks. They don't want people opposing the dominant Peoples Action Party (PAP) founded by Lee Kuan Yew who have been in power since 1965.
4. No drugs, porn, and prostitution. But prostitution is still lurking around. Heavy censorship of media. Straits Times is managed by the ex-government official like a Chinese business. Media is owned by the state owned Mediacorp: Channel 5 (English) and Channel 8 (Chinese) news. Porn is illegal and blocked. The police WILL go after you if you have smuggle it in. Protest illegal unless you are licensed by government to speak in speakers corner which no one cares. Opposition parties are fined and jailed so they don't ever win. PAP makes sure opposition look stupid.
5. Mandatory military service for all males due to the threat from bigger neighbors (Aka. Malaysia and Indonesia).
6. Increasing Xenophobia for foreigners due to lack of housing space for everyone. Prices have been rising leading to cramp apartments like the Hong Kong situation.
7. Raising inequality. More homeless on the streets.
8. Central Provident Fund not sustainable.
9. More Flash Floods. Raising water levels. Singapore is at sea level. They need land reclamation otherwise they sink.
10. Han Chinese Singaporean majority. Good luck if you are the minority. Constant reports of abuse of domestic workers from Indonesia and Phillipines. Low accommodations for Indian construction workers. Alot of Singapore's labor workforce is foreign and lowly paid and poorly treated.

Excellent video, well balanced. However it fails to recognize (or fails to emphasize) that a key ingredient of success is simply strategic location. Singapore is a trading hub, and this is the key to its success (good government, educated and hard working workforce, rule of law, low taxes are relevant but secondary to its success). In fact, all cities / small countries / colonies / overseas territories in comparable situations are also wealthy: Panama, Gibraltar, New York, Rotterdam, London, Dubai, Shanghai, (and in older days Istanbul, Venice or Genoa) are all trading hubs of some sort. The common reason for their wealth is not smart government, rule of law, educated people or low taxes but the simple fact that due to their location stuff or money transit through them.

It's hard to reconcile Singapore's success had it existed where the Falkland Islands are now. In other words, although strategically vulnerable from invasion from a hostile Asian power (such as happened in 1942), Singapore position is one of the best placed to capitalise on international trade and shipping routes. That helps enormously. Lee Kuan Yew is the most interesting despot in recent human history because his oppression of free speech was not driven by his desires to line his pockets (and those with all his families and associates as well). Resisting this obvious temptation puts him way ahead ethically of many other dictators. Furthermore, unlike the one-party state CCP, the virtual one party PAP is driven by pragmatic market-driven authoritarianism and not by failed Marxist ideology. I understand the social and race frictions and riots that periodically broke out in Singapore before the 1980's that may have lead to Lee's repression to control this, and relative lack of democracy in Singapore. It seems to me that Singapore's development has somewhat mirrored that of Taiwan, albeit that Taiwan is in a more perilous strategic condition than Singapore is now. This was not always the case, and may not be into the future. The global trade system that dominated the globe by the US Navy protection of everyone's trade's routes for 40 years is by now breaking down. This puts increasing pressure on a small trade-oriented countries like Singapore to beef up it's navy and air force to protect it's sea lanes. Without regional concourse, particularly with Malaysia and Indonesia, Singapore may find an unpleasant competitive arms build-up and increasing friction with it's near neighbours, and of course with CCP China which is increasingly becoming belligerent in the region.

Singapore's lessons can't be applied to majority of countries. It's so small and relatively culturally homogenized that it could pull off a lot of authoritarian stunts that wouldn't work elsewhere, like banning unions and repressing the media and homosexual groups.

Lee's knack was to get ordinary Singaporeans to trust him and his agenda, while being saavy enough to know how much he could get away with in terms of less savoury practices. Like heavy handed control over the media, detaining political prisoners without trial, nobbling opposition parties, and ensuring a "compliant judiciary". These methods were accepted at a time when people were more pre-occupied with earning a living, getting a roof over their heads or avoiding race riots. They are less likely to be accepted by Singaporeans today, most of whom have grown up with full bellies and a more educated world view. It will be interesting to see how durable a legacy Lee has passed on to his successors. 

It is very easy to praise Singapore's achievements (which are very real and well deserved) when you compare them against the backwardness and incompetence of governing regimes in nearby SE Asian countries. Increasingly however, Singapore's benchmark will up against other countries in the first world it has now joined.

Lee Kuan Yew, is a perfect example of what you would call a Wise Dictator. He did not rule in a dictatorship for the sake of power, but for the benefit of the signaporian  people and their future and took the necessary measures to implement that. 

Under a wise Dictator, you can do wonders. But under a bad Dictator, they will make it like a hell on earth. 

He was a Unicorn, or the exception to the rule. While he was great and has led Signapore into what it is today and has brought great prosperity. He is a exception to the rule not the norm. The thing with Dictators is that you can't pick the good from the bad, and you can't guarantee they won't become corrupt with power, because greed is naturally in human nature. While he was great for the people there are no Assurances his successors will be the same. It only takes one bad Dictator to severely hurt the nation. It's the same problem the old Absolute Monarchy system, under a good king you had peace and prosperity. But under a bad one, you probably had hell on earth. 

That's what makes a Democratic form of government so great, it assumes you can't completely trust its leadership, so before a leader could really damage the country too much you can easily replace them. It mitigates the risk, but it does mitigate a bit of the potential gains under a good leader too though. But in most instances of Autocratic rule, generally they are more bad than good.

The miraculous transformation of a "backwater fishing village" story is LKY's propaganda myth. Victors rewrite history to their benefit. At independence, Singapore was already a leading economic center and thriving port in Asia, poised for success. All the banks and entrepreneurs already set up shop in Singapore. 

The majority of Singaporeans lived in Kampongs, not slums. But of course, LKY categorized them as slums on purpose. Many older Singaporeans value and hold fond memories of Kampong life, and they tell me its a pity that the younger generation would never get to experience what Kampong life was like. 

At independence in 1965, Singapore's GDP per capita was $517, many times higher than many of these countries: South Korea at $108, China at $97, Thailand at $138, Burma at $17, Taiwan at $225. 

In 1965, Singapore was the fourth richest country in Asia, behind only Japan, HK and Brunei (oil reserves). Singapore had a head start, and its economic transformation was not any more miraculous than HK, Taiwan or South Korea.

It may have been shocking to see a nation eject part of itself and forcibly give it 'independence'. But on hindsight, this act should be done more often to reduce the number of internal conflicts that would have torn the entire country apart. The reason for Singapore's ejection was because  Lee Kuan Yew, the leader of Singapore which was a Malaysian state that had a large Chinese population wanted more equal rights for all the races in entire the country Malaysia, whereas the majority Malay population wanted to retain their special position being the natives of that country. Apart from the Malays and the Chinese, there were also a significant Indian population in Malaysia. Dragging it out could have resulted in a civil war like you see in so many countries all over the world. As it was there were already several racial riots in that country during those days in which many were killed. Today Malaysia and Singapore live peacefully with one another as neighbors with close social and economic cooperation rather than a squabbling family under one roof. Other countries should learn from this. This is not rocket science. If a married couple can't get along, then just get divorce and follow your own path. Why force yourself to live together in pain, misery and anger.

you mentioned 3 points where singapore "got lucky", it was a good summary but in my view i woudn't attribute them to luck alone. Thought that would be more accurate to say that it was 
1) blessed with its geographic location (this was just the natural situation it was in and I wouldn't classify it as luck; it was more "lucky" in the sense that we had managed to identify and leverage on it to extract economic value, but that was also born out of smarts and not luck per se); 
2) it fought hard to catch the wave of the economic growth (this was not luck, it was out of effort and sacrifice from the people at the time, and in the scheme of things economic waves happen all the time in different forms and industries depending on how you look at it), 
and 3) it only got lucky in having LKY leading it at that time (where he could have easily been "more corrupted" with power to the detriment of the country, and we got lucky that he had acted with great foresight, principles/integrity, and decisiveness). 

And also while LKY deserves much of the credit, the focus on him tends to overlook the other brilliant work done by other individuals, public agencies, and private citizens and businesses. I think it is worth emphasizing that it took concerted effort and it is not a one man job.

I get that this was thumbnail bait, but you know Malaysia isn't really poor per se, right? Like, yeah, it's not Singapore rich, but it still does pretty well in most economic and human development metrics, at least in comparison to other countries in Southeast Asia. Not to mention it never backslid into an autocratic regime quite as hard; even today, in spite of the 1MDB scandal and political crisis, Malaysia has a significantly higher Democracy Index score (7.24 vs 6.23) than Singapore does.

And yeah, Malaysia definitely has its issues in that regard, enshrining Islam and "Malay-ness" in its constitution and the entire shitshow that is the NEP. But all of these comments praising Singapore's economic growth, by any means necessary, at the general expense of human rights, liberties, democratic governance and the rule of law, leaves a pretty sour taste in my mouth. All y'all armchair economists need to learn what an externality is.

I first visited Singapore in 1972 at the age of 22. From a distance, I saw a space like structure which I later know that it's the immgration and custom departments. My first impression as I reached the Singapore end of the courseway and I noticed the sparkling clean waters on either side of the entrance. As I went into Singapore, I noticed lots of trees lining the roads. Flower plants on all the overhead bridges. Many high rise apartments and buildings. No rubbish to be found anywhere. There are NO public canings. And internet access to all social media is freely available. LKY did not sue political opponents as sport. There was always the lies and false accusations initiated by Opposition politicians first. You need to speak to some employed singaporeans.

Hard Truths:
1) Singapore wasn’t “kicked out”. LKY engineered the independence by openly supporting the political opponents of Tunku Abdul Rahman (the man without whom Singapore would remained a British colony) thus making Singapore’s position in Malaysia untenable. LKY made his crocodile tears announcement on TV of Singapore’s independence before Tunku had actually signed the deed of separation. All this is evidenced in the Hansard.

2) The fact that some of those political opponents LKY supported were pro-communist (and the PAP being a recently-communist party before LKY engineered the sacking of its leaders and assumed control) only further inflamed the Malayans who spilled blood defending their new country against communist insurgents in the north. The friend of my enemy can’t be my friend.

3) a sleepy village third world country Singapore was not. It was the jewel of the British crown colonies, had a robust civil service and sophisticated infrastructure and the region’s most developed ports. Singapore had the 3rd largest GDP in Asia after WWII. LKY basically inherited the good work of his predecessors and claimed it as his own doing. 

4) Here’s what Singapore got from its supposedly “hostile neighbour” since independence:
- a free airline (MSA > SIA) and a monopoly on international routes 
- endless supply of cheap sand, water and labour, without which none of its much vaunted success would have been achieved 
- ZERO threats despite Singapore’s military arming itself to the teeth and openly practicing war games

But Singapore needs its boogeyman Malaysia to keep its citizens in fear. 

5) Singapore is the last country on earth that has not changed its government. The only others are North Korea, China and Cuba.

6) It also has the world’s highest MP:electorate ratio. This plus the world’s only electoral system that requires constituents to elect 5 member teams instead of individual representatives means that its political hegemony is ensured in perpetuity.

7) no other country practices state capitalism quite like Singapore. Public housing, transport, healthcare and utilities are provided at grossly inflated prices to provide bumper profits to state-owned corporations. 

8) The rules are always tilted to favour the rich. Singapore launders everyone’s money. 

9) LKY openly advocated state sponsored eugenics. Women were sterilised to reduce birth rates. LKY then used the low birth rates to justify importing foreigners and new citizens by the millions to reduce the native-born population. You know who else favoured eugenics? Hitler. 

10) LKY is but one man. Like Gandhi, Washington or Churchill, every country needs one leader to propel the country forward. A great man perhaps, but his creation is a perfect veneer that masks giant social and economic fissures.

you also have to consider the problems that our superior healthcare has caused: our rapidly aging population means there's an even larger emphasis on healthcare, and a large percentage of our population are not in the working class. this has sparked policies of re-employment of the older generation, and also, implementation of various employment policies which prioritise singaporeans (TAFEP). our lack of land has lead to reclamation efforts doubling down (with the building of terminal 5 of the changi airport, we'll have the first airport built on reclaimed land). speaking about the airport, the changi airport has been one of the best (if not the best) in the world for many many years. the emphasis on education has created a draconian curriculum, that while competitive, has increased adolescent stress and depression rates exponentially. singapore is an incredibly multifaceted society which has been forced to walk the tightrope since the very beginning, in the context of the cold war when it gained independence. it traded with the soviet union, rejected western influence, (so it could join the UN, and maintain US interest in the region) and formed ASEAN (to gain an equal say in the region, prevent the vastly larger Indonesia from gaining unparalleled power within SEA) in order to maintain its fragile sovereignty, and it would not have been possible without LKY.

A very good effort at covering Singapore's history, although your value-laden judgment did leak through your narrative. But that is understandable. The problem with narrating history is that knowing what we know now, we are tempted and seduced into thinking that the past was working towards a predetermined future. So it is tempting to assume that Lee Kuan Yew aimed to get Singapore rich, and was ruthless (and unprincipled?) in his self-appointed task of prospering Singapore, and that everything he did was to achieve that goal. That is a fallacious assumption. 
If I could ask LKY a question, my question would be, "why?" Why did he choose to try to lead Singapore. He was a lawyer, trained in England, and could, if he wanted, worked there as a lawyer. There was nothing to hold him in Singapore. There was not even an idea of "Singapore" as a city-state. Before 1963, he returned to a post-war Singapore devastated by the Japanese Occupation (that part of the video was very emotive and evocative!) The British had returned (to try to make amends for their betrayal?) and sought to re-establish some semblence of order and civilisation. But they were a waning power and couldn't wait to have an excuse to pull out of Singapore. 
Lee believed in the (conventional) wisdom that Singapore could not survive on its own and worked desperately towards merger with Malaysia.  And when that did not work out, and Singapore separated from Malaysia, Lee cried on TV.
At that point, he could have just thrown in the towel, pack his bags and leave for the UK to be the lawyer he trained to be. Why didn't he? 
Instead, he "decided" he wanted to stay in Singapore and be the dictator that many western "scholars" see him to be? :-) If Singapore had gold, diamonds, oil or other natural resources that he could steal and exploit, maybe (curse of natural resources). We had (back then) hungry people, disease, heat, humidity, and unemployment. For me, that is the more interesting question.
BUT... I did not mean to be... petty. This is a pretty well-researched narrative, and for a non-Singaporean, quite objective. I don't agree with some of what you said/conclude/judged, but that is only human. And there are lots of nuances and side issues (e.g. comparing HK and Singapore's housing). I can't help but smile when you noted that Singapore had "affordable housing", and can imagine the hordes of Singaporeans who will crucify you for that (I am not one of them, tho!). :-)
Anyway, to be clear, great job!

Lee Kuan Yew is a fascinating individual. He did what he had to do to make sure his country developed from a socially and economically suppressed state to a global financial and trading juggernaut.

They have several phases, but in term of core strength: strong institution, strong work culture, stability preference leadership, they managed to grow impressively. What's more interesting is not just this, we have had numerous cases of great leaders leading economic miracle on for their work to crumble soon after they die. One interesting way the Singapore ruling faction holds itself and various other members accountable is tying their success long term with Singapore long term success. Their stake in government owned investment funds directly related to how well they were managing their job. This is almost similar to paying employees in company shares, but a little more complicated with many strings tied. Then, there's the transition. Singapore went from a manufacturing, port hub to a strong financial centre due to circumstance. Singapore was rich and stable throughout the turbulent years compare to their neighbours. Much of their wealth were generated then reinvest through government held hedge fund. These funds were then invested into businesses around, from plantation to real estate in their neighbours. They went in with money to rising economies like China, Vietnam then Burma which bore fruit until this very day. That's how they managed to transform from a manufacturer to an investor so successfully. Their model is essentially what China had adopted since the 80s.

It's really interesting when a nation succeeds by doing the opposite of what much of the received wisdom at the time dictated.  How much of the lessons are applicable to Europe or the West or even China is debatable - simply because tiny island nationalities such as Singapore, Taiwan, or HK can leverage their size and lack of imperial or geographic commitments to radically change or market themselves in a way broad, geographically large nations cannot.  Applying the lessons of Singapore to the UK for instance might mean you end up with an even more extreme City of London thriving while the rest of the country is a barren wasteland.

Two things. First it should be emphasized just counter to contemporary prevailing wisdom what Singapore did was.

While other post colonial countries embraced anti trade, socialist ideas that were in vogue, Singapore took the risk to focus on trade. His idea that Singapore will eventually move up the value chain is now completely vindicated. This ran counter to the then popular idea that international trade merely exploited third world countries.

Secondly I don't think he at any time banned Unions completely. He just severely legally restricted when debilitating strikes could take place. The context here is the the Unions were the stronghold of his communist opposition and could have been used to further their political goals.
